awd_titl_txt: Analytic and Algebraic Methods in Discrete Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the PI's research in building mathematical tools to solve combinatorial problems in Discrete Geometry. Discrete geometry studies fundamental geometric objects, such as points, lines and circles, and their combinatorial properties. Thus most combinatorial problems in Discrete Geometry are quite visual and can be presented in a simple manner: What is the minimum total width of strips that cover a unit disk in the plane? Or, what is the maximum number of lines through the origin pairwise separated by the same angle? In contrast to the simple appearances of these problems, many of these problems, including the ones considered in this project, remain unsolved for an extended period or have been partly solved only recently following great efforts. This project aims to further develop the toolbox of available approaches, most of which are analytic or algebraic in nature. Simultaneously, the project integrates these research problems and themes into educational and outreach activities that extend from the high school level to the graduate.

The first topic of this project concerns extensions and variations of Tarski's plank problem: How to efficiently cover a convex body in the plane using planks? Generalizations of Tarski’s plank problem are central to geometric analysis and convex geometry, and continue to generate interest in the geometric and analytic aspects of coverings of a convex body. The second topic concerns equiangular lines —- a collection of lines through the origin pairwise separated by the same angle. Investigation of the equiangular lines problem turns out to be fruitful and unearthed many challenging problems in algebraic graph theory. Solutions to some problems have practical consequences in Operational Research, Quantum Computation and Communication Theory. Previous foundational work, including some done by the PI, has shown that tools and insights from Ramsey Theory, Extremal Combinatorics, Probabilistic Methods, Spectral Graph Theory, Algebraic Combinatorics, Topological Combinatorics, and Algebraic Geometry can be helpful in solving the problems in this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary focus of our project has been to explore equiangular lines and spherical two-distance sets and their intriguing connection to graph theory. These seemingly abstract concepts have profound implications in both mathematics and its applications.

Equiangular Lines and Spherical Two-Distance Sets

Imagine a collection of lines converging at a single point and spreading outwards, each pair forming equal angles. These configurations, known as "equiangular lines", have captivated mathematicians for over seven decades. The enduring question is: how large can these sets be, especially when considering higher-dimensional spaces beyond the usual three dimensions?

In simpler scenarios, equiangular lines are easy to spot. For example, in a two-dimensional setting, connecting opposite vertices of a hexagon creates three lines, each intersecting at a 60-degree angle. In a three-dimensional space, connecting opposite vertices of an icosahedron results in six intersecting lines, with each pair forming a 63.4-degree angle.

To gain a better understanding of these line sets, we associate each line with a vector pointing in a specific direction. By analyzing the "dot product" of these vectors (a mathematical operation that yields a scalar value), we can determine if the angle between them is acute or obtuse. This methodology forms the foundation of our study.

Research Contributions and Findings

Building on previous work, my collaborator, Polyanskii, and I proposed a general formula for the maximum number of equiangular lines in a ddd-dimensional space with a specified angle. We introduced a parameter related to graph theory, which studies how points (or vectors, in this case) are connected by edges. In our scenario, we color the edges between points red if the dot product is positive and blue if the dot product is negative. This visualization helps us understand the original problem in a new way.

During the Summer Program of Undergraduate Research (SPUR) at MIT in 2019, my colleagues Tidor, Yao, Zhang, Zhao, and I solved this longstanding problem of equiangular lines. Our work connected the problem of equiangular lines with spectral graph theory, which uses linear algebra to study graphs, particularly focusing on the eigenvalues of these graphs.

Expanding on this momentum, our team investigated the generalized problem of spherical two-distance sets. This problem involves vectors forming two fixed angles, not necessarily complementary. We proposed a conjecture on the maximum number of such vectors and confirmed it for several pairs of angles. These findings are detailed in our publication, "Spherical two-distance sets and eigenvalues of signed graphs" [1].

In another study, Polyanskii and I delved deeper into the realm of graphs with both positive and negative edges. We discovered that understanding these variations could significantly enhance our knowledge of spherical two-distance sets, as documented in our paper "Forbidden induced subgraphs for graphs and signed graphs with eigenvalues bounded from below" [2].

Inspired by our success, my graduate student, Acharya, and I further explored the eigenvalues of graphs, resulting in new insights and potential confirmations of our previous conjectures. Our results are presented in "Beyond the classification theorem of Cameron, Goethals, Seidel, and Shult" [3].

Impact and Future Directions

Our research has not only advanced the theoretical understanding of equiangular lines and spherical two-distance sets but has also opened up new avenues for investigation in graph theory and beyond. The connections we have established between these areas highlight the interdisciplinary nature of modern mathematical research and its potential to foster significant breakthroughs.

Publications

  1. Spherical two-distance sets and eigenvalues of signed graphs
    Z. Jiang, J. Tidor, Y. Yao, S. Zhang, Y. Zhao
    Combinatorica, 43(2), 203-232

  2. Forbidden induced subgraphs for graphs and signed graphs with eigenvalues bounded from below
    Z. Jiang, A. Polyanskii
    arXiv preprint, arXiv:2111.10366

  3. Beyond the classification theorem of Cameron, Goethals, Seidel, and Shult
    H. Acharya, Z. Jiang
    arXiv preprint, arXiv:2404.13136

Our ongoing work continues to explore the rich interplay between algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structures, with the promise of uncovering further mathematical marvels.
